Content_wSideColumn.BodyCopy:
Many companies have policies about hiring family members, as it can be seen as a conflict of interest to do so. Some limit policies to prohibiting someone from supervising his/her own family member.

If a student has been hired or accepted as an intern at a company where another family member works, additional consideration must be given to the circumstance, and the experience may be considered as an "exception" - for which additional documentation is required.

Guidelines which require additional documentation:

  • Working in a business which a family member owns, manages, etc.
  • Working directly for a family member - who will act as supervisor, department manager, etc.
  • Working indirectly for a family member - who is in the line management of the intern's supervisor.
  • Other situations which would cause a conflict of interest for work assignments, fair assessment and evaluations, etc.

Note: In large corporations where there is not a direct working relationship, these guidelines may not apply. For example, in a large retail chain, if the intern is working in the Accounting department, and the family member works in the Garden department, no conflict of interest is typically involved.

As an intern, if you are working in a business with another family member, please contact the Academic Discovery Center for more information on whether or not the exception will apply.
